newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia rebel rejects Samper peace plan - TV.
newsitem.headline: Colombia rebel rejects Samper peace plan - TV.

text.p: The leader of Colombia's second largest guerrilla army ordered his regional commanders not to negotiate a peace deal with President Ernesto Samper's government, local media reported Sunday.

The NTC TV news programme quoted parts of an alleged phone conversation between Manuel Perez, head of the National Liberation Army (ELN), and a local guerrilla chief, said to have been intercepted by military intelligence.
"Corruption makes him (Samper) an illegitimate authority ... he constantly says one thing and then breaks his word," Perez said on the recording.

Perez, a radical Roman Catholic priest originally from Spain's northern Basque region, said, however, that he would talk to members of the Church-led National Conciliation Commission to study possible peace proposals.
The Perez recording came a week after two of the ELN's jailed leaders described Samper's calls for peace talks, backed by a group of Colombia's top industrialists, as a "significant development."
Samper floated the idea of a new peace process after the largest of the country's three rebel forces, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), released 70 troops on June 15.

The rebels had been holding 60 of the soldiers prisoner for more than nine months. At a handover ceremony in a temporarily demilitarized region of southern Colombia, the FARC's supreme leader Manuel "Sureshot" Marulanda said he would be ready to sit down and hammer out a plan for "peace with social justice".

But he set a series of tough pre-conditions, including the demilitarization of other areas and the break-up of right-wing paramilitary groups, that the government seems unlikely or unwilling to be able to meet.
Some political analysts suggested the Cuban-inspired ELN, set up by radical Roman Catholic priests in 1966, may agree to peace talks more readily than the FARC.
But the Perez recording appears to torpedo any real hopes of starting a new process to end Latin America's longest-running guerrilla war before Samper leaves office next August.
